#Text=Roderick Maclean
#Text=For the Canadian politician , see Roderick MacLean .
#Text=For the Scottish bishop , see Roderick MacLean ( bishop ) .
#Text=Roderick Edward Maclean
#Text=( c.1854 – 8 June 1921 ) was a Scotsman who attempted to assassinate Queen Victoria on 2 March 1882 , at Windsor , England , with a pistol .
#Text=This was the last of eight attempts by separate people to kill or assault Victoria over a period of four decades .
#Text=Maclean 's motive was purportedly a curt reply to some poetry that he had mailed to the Queen . [ 4 ]
#Text=The attempted murder followed the arrival of the Royal train , conveying the Queen , Princess Beatrice and the Court from Windsor .

#Text=Queen Victoria had just walked across the platform of Windsor station to a carriage in waiting when Maclean , who was standing at the entrance of the station yard among a number of spectators , deliberately fired a revolver at her .

#Text=The shot missed , and Maclean was seized by Chief Superintendent Hayes , of the Borough Police , and the weapon wrenched from his grasp by someone in the crowd . – Birmingham Daily Gazette , 1921 [ 5 ]
#Text=Other accounts state that the revolver was a toy and that his aim was disrupted by an Eton schoolboy :
#Text=The weapon was a mere toy , and the life the beloved monarch was not seriously endangered .

#Text=A number of Eton boys were round the station at the time , and one of them rushed forward and struck Maclean with his umbrella , disconcerting his aim — which was unlikely enough , in any case , to have been accurate .
#Text=The boy in question , Gordon Wilson , was called to the Castle by her Majesty and thanked for his promptitude .
#Text=He was the son of Sir Samuel Wilson , the Australian wool magnate , who introduced salmon into the Australian rivers and afterwards sat in Parliament for a short time for Portsmouth .
#Text=Gordon Wilson married Lady Sarah Spencer-Churchill , a sister of Lord Randolph and Lady Wimborne .
#Text=He was killed in the early days of the war .
#Text=The wretched lunatic , therefore , survived all the other chief actors in his poor little drama , paying dearly for his brief notoriety .
#Text=He had , however , the distinction of undergoing trial for high treason . –
#Text=Lichfield Mercury

#Text=At his trial , Dr. Charles Vernon Hitchins testified that MacLean had been certified insane in June 1880 , two years before the attempted assassination , and he had been sent to Somerset Lunatic Asylum .
#Text=He was living 14 , Wadham Street in Weston-super-Mare .

#Text=Dr. Hitchins stated that Maclean was complaining of headaches and believed that all the people in England are against him , and he felt he must injure someone because they are conspiring to deceive him .

#Text=He had also sent letters to his sister in 1880 , Caroline Maclean , stating that , " If I cannot commit a murder one way , I will another way , and all can add is , if there is more difficulty , there may be more victims .

#Text= Multiple doctors also testified that Maclean was insane and " did not believe he was capable of appreciating the nature or quality of any act which he might commit .

#Text=Tried for high treason on 20 April , the Scotsman was found  not guilty , but insane " by a jury after five minutes ' deliberation , overseen by Lord Chief Justice Coleridge .

column1: #Text=and he lived out his remaining days in Broadmoor Asylum .

#Text=The verdict prompted the Queen to ask for a change in English law so that those implicated in cases with similar outcomes would be considered as " guilty , but insane " ; this led to the Trial of Lunatics Act 1883 . [ 7 ] [ 8 ]
#Text=A poem was later written about Maclean 's attempt on the Queen 's life by William Topaz McGonagall . [ 9 ]
